content.description:
A short route that ends at a ledge underneath the large, overhanging dihedral.

The coldshuts for this route are way off to the right, so I would not recommend top-roping this route.

The only real purpose of this route is to get to the nice route above it.
content.protection: Four bolts that lead to coldshuts, which are placed several feet to the right.
content.location: The first route to the left of the large, overhanging dihedral.

content.description: Slightly steep jug pulling through the guano stained blocks leads to a no-hands rest. If you are feeling pumped, get it all back because the second part of this route is crimping on smaller holds. Unfortunately, the crux of this route is clipping the anchors. It would have made more sense to place the anchors down a couple of feet where they could have been clipped from the jug. Instead, find a sidepull that you like better than the others and place your right foot on the higher of the two choices.
content.protection: 7 welded cold-shuts to an anchor of 2 welded cold-shuts.
content.location: Starts in the guano and then heads left. It is also the fifth route left of the approach trail.

content.description:
Climb a nice strip of rock with a black water streak in the middle of the pitch. This shares an anchor with

Brown Bottle Flu

.
content.location:
It is just left of "

It's Your Call

," 5.10.

content.description:
This is a crack route that has been bolted. It protects well with gear -- skip the bolts.

This overhanging dihedral with a crack running through it is much easier than it looks.
content.protection: Skip the bolts and bring gear. #0.5, #0.75, and #1 cams might require doubles. There are coldshuts at the top.

content.description:
This link provides a more logical and smooth way to climb the classic

Shock the Monkey

corner without climbing

Trash Man

(out left) and trying to manage the rope from there or set up an intermediate belay on the ledge. There is an old 1/4" bolt and other evidence that Doug Ranck and others explored this possibility but evidently didn't finish it.

Climb the first three bolts of

Toxic Substance

. At the fourth bolt, reach left to a new bolt connecting the blank face between

Toxic Substance

and the ledge system below

Shock the Monkey's

classic corner. You may want to clip the fourth bolt while making this reach and then back clean the fourth bolt. Slings or long draws may also be helpful in this section.

Make this long move left and on to the first of two ledge systems below

Shock the Monkey's

corner. A new bolt up and right of the old two bolt anchor below the corner helps the rope run more freely. Once in the corner of

Shock the Monkey

, climb the steep, right-angling corner.
content.location:
Start as for

Toxic Substance

on the far left of the main sector of the Dump Wall. This is a link-up of the bottom of

Toxic Substance

and into

Shock the Monkey

.

content.description:
Climb

Dump Monkeyâ€™s

first 2 bolts, head right to clip 3 bolts, then continue right, and finish on

Bear in A Dumpster

. This is a super fun endurance pitch!
content.location:
Start on "

Dump Monkey

," and head right after the 2nd bolt.

content.description: A thin, bouldery start leads to bigger holds.
content.protection: 5 welded cold-shuts to an anchor of 2 welded cold-shuts.
content.location: This is the first route left of the approach trail.

content.description:
This would be a classic route if it weren't for having to dodge a little guano and a couple sections of flaking rock.

Regardless, the movement is spectacular.

If you aren't pumped by the time you get to the first set of anchors, there is a 3 bolt extension that goes through an overhanging dihedral (11c).
content.protection: 7 welded cold-shuts to an anchor of 2 cold-shuts that are bent closed but not welded.
content.location: This is the fourth route left of the approach trail and is easily found by looking for the route that is just right of the dark streak of guano covered rock.

content.description:
Climb "

Dance Monkey

," 5.12, then continue up and right onto a steep arete. There are fun boulder problems and nice positioning on this pitch.
content.location:
It is just right of "

Bear in A Dumpster

," 5.12+.

content.description:
Climb first 3 bolts of

Brown Bottle Flu

, then head up and left on gently overhanging, white rock to an anchor above a huge jug rail. It is nice to stickclip the first bolt.
content.location:
It is just right of "

Bear in A Dumpster

," 5.12+, and starts on "

Brown Bottle Flu

".

content.description: This has good, juggy climbing on light colored rock. It climbs more technical than it looks!
content.location: It is right of the main face. Start on yellow rock.

content.description: This is a route of two contrasting halves. The first half is thin, thought-provoking slab climbing; the second half is slightly overhanging climbing on good holds.
content.protection: 7 welded cold-shuts to an anchor of 2 welded cold-shuts.
content.location: This is the second route left of the approach trail.

content.description: A slab crux getting to the third bolt will keep you on your toes, but the climbing is anything but over as the route stays a bit continuous. The upper headwall consists of big, steep, fun moves on good holds.
content.protection: 12 bolts to an anchor of two coldshuts.
content.location: The third route to the left of the approach trail.
